repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh -  Fourth Population &
            Health and Health & Population Program Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This assessment concurred with the
            completion report ratings of the Fourth Population and
            Health Project (FPHP) in Bangladesh.  For the Health and
            Population Program Project (HPPP) it differed in the rating
            of modest institutional development impact and an
            unsatisfactory performance of the Bank.  The two projects
            have made a clear and demonstrable contribution to the
            Bangladesh's remarkable success in reducing fertility
            and under-five mortality.  Lessons learned include the
            following: aid-financed health infrastructure can work in
            improving health outcomes provided other conditions are in
            place; public and private provision are complements not
            substitutes; a sector wide approach (SWAP) takes time to
            implement and is an evolutionary process; wide stakeholder
            participation in preparation helps ownership but can weaken
            design; think through the implications of the new system;
            draw on the appropriate skills mix; failure to assess fully
            the political economy of reform and to prepare both a
            proactive plan for addressing/mitigating risks and a
            contingency plan will considerably diminish prospects for
            successful reform; too much donor/Bank intervention can
            undermine government capacity and ownership of a SWAP
            approach; and finally, be realistic in tackling major reform objectives.

repnme.cdata!: Bangladesh - Fourth Population and Health Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory. Key
            lessons learned are: 1) Although long-term commitment to the
            sector on the part of International Development Association
            (IDA) and other development partners will continue to be
            essential to the progress of the sector, the project did not
            effectively address program sustainability or the reduction
            of continued dependence on external financing. 2) The
            IDA-led donor consortium largely achieved its aid
            coordination objectives, thereby reducing Ministry of Health
            and Family Welfare's management burden in terms of
            donor relations and facilitating relatively flexible
            financing arrangements. 3) The projectized approach to the
            utilization of donor resources was inefficient in a variety
            of ways and undermined the Ministry's ability to manage
            its program. 4) The delivery of health and family welfare
            services through separate Directorates continued to be
            inefficient and in important respects limited effectiveness.
            5) Despite extremely limited public resources, pressures on
            Government to fund expensive tertiary facilities and
            curative care proved difficult to resist. A public sector
            focus on priority funding for the most cost-effective basic
            services is needed. 6) The successful delivery of services
            by nongovernmental organizations in cooperation with
            Government suggests that this approach could usefully be expanded.

repnme.cdata!: Bangladesh - Fourth Population and Health Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project components are to: (a)
            strengthen family planning (FP) services delivery; (b)
            strengthen health services delivery; (c) improve supportive
            activities to the delivery of FP and health services; and
            (d) continue women's and nutrition programs. FP service
            delivery will be strengthened by improving access to FP
            services, strengthening mother and child health (MCH)
            services, enhancing clinical service delivery and quality
            assurance, imparting in-service training of upazila and
            district staff, constructing and renovating facilities, and
            marketing contraceptives through the private sector. The
            project will strengthen health service delivery by
            increasing the range of maternal and neonatal health care
            services, strengthening nursing and medical education,
            introducing medical quality assurance, supporting medical
            research, strengthening disease prevention and control,
            developing urban primary health care, continuing and
            expanding school health programs, improving district and
            upazila health facilities, and improving the utilization of
            upazila health centers. The project will assist in
            strengthening information systems, improving FP and health
            management, expanding communications programs, supporting
            nongovernmental organization activities, and developing
            innovative projects. Finally, the project will assist with
            the continuation of three women's programs financed
            under previous projects and will strengthen and develop the
            National Nutrition Council.
